facts.text: Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution raises the question of the validity of r. 16 of the Madras General Sales Tax Turnover Assessment Rules, 1939.
Impugned rule published on September 7, 1955, substituted old r. 16, effective from April 1, 1955.
Petitioner is a dealer in hides and skins, sells hides and skins tanned outside the State of Madras as well as those tanned inside the State.

Deputy Commercial Tax Officer, 1, Moore Market Division, Madras, assessed petitioner to sales tax for the year 1955-56 on a turnover of Rs. 29,89,624-15-11, out of which Rs. 28,10,625-2-0 represented sales of tanned hides and skins obtained from outside the State of Madras.
Sales tax levied on hides and skins under Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 (Act IX of 1939).
Section 3(1) of the Act: every dealer shall pay tax on total turnover at three pies per rupee.
Section 5(vi): sale of hides and skins, tanned or untanned, liable to tax under s.3(1) only at single point in series of sales as prescribed.
Section 19 empowers State Government to make rules.
New r.16(1): tax on untanned hides/skins levied from last purchaser in State exempt from s.3(3), on purchase price.
r.16(2)(i): tax on hides/skins tanned outside State levied from first dealer in State exempt from s.3(3), on sale price.

r.16(2)(ii): tax on hides/skins tanned within State levied from first dealer exempt from s.3(3), on sale price, but proviso: not liable if proves tax already levied under sub-r.(1) on untanned hides/skins.
Burden of proving transaction not liable under rule on dealer.

legal_issues.text: Whether r.16 of the Madras General Sales Tax Turnover Assessment Rules, 1939, is valid, particularly whether it discriminates against imported tanned hides/skins in violation of Art. 304(a) of the Constitution.
Whether sales tax comes within purview of Art. 304(a).
Whether impugned rule is a law made by State Legislature.
Maintainability of petition in view of Ujjam Bai v. State of UP.

petitioner_arguments.text: Effect of rule is that tanned hides/skins imported from outside State and sold within State subject to higher rate of tax than those tanned and sold within State, as tax on imported is on sale price, while on local is effectively on raw purchase price due to proviso, which is substantially less.
Hides/skins imported raw from outside, then tanned inside State subject to higher tax (on tanned sale price) than those purchased raw inside and tanned inside (on raw purchase price).

respondent_arguments.text: Sales tax does not come within purview of Art. 304(a) as it is not tax on import at point of entry.
Impugned rule not a law made by State Legislature.
Rule does not impose tax but fixes single point for tax under ss.3 and 5.
Rule made out of necessity due to statutory requirement for single point tax on raw or tanned hides/skins, not with eye on place of origin.
If rule invalid, old r.16 revives, assessment valid.
Petition not maintainable per Ujjam Bai.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ujjam Bai v. State of UP

court_reasoning.text: Sales tax can restrict trade under Art.301 if hampers flow and not compensatory/regulatory; discriminatory sales tax offends Art.301 and valid only under Art.304(a).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Taxes directly/immediately restricting trade fall under Art.301; sales tax here discriminatory.

court_reasoning.text: Art.304(a) not limited to border imposts; applies to taxes on goods from other States unless similar tax on local goods.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Imposition need not be at point of entry.

court_reasoning.text: Rule made under s.19 has statutory force as if enacted in Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rule is law for Art.304(a) purposes.

court_reasoning.text: Rule part of tax imposition machinery; discriminatory fixing of single point invalid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discriminates via proviso allowing credit for local raw tax but not imported.

court_reasoning.text: r.16(2)(i) and (ii) similar but proviso to (ii) exempts local tanned if raw tax paid, leading to tax on lower raw price for local vs sale price for imported; even raw imported then tanned inside taxed higher.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Substantial price disparity makes tax higher on imported despite same rate.

court_reasoning.text: Prior tax on raw does not make goods different kind; discrimination based on origin.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Similarity under Art.304(a) is in quality/kind of tanned goods, not prior tax.

court_reasoning.text: Old r.16 does not revive on invalidation of new.
Petition maintainable as taxing officer lacked jurisdiction due to invalid rule, unlike Ujjam Bai.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not mere misconstruction of valid Act.

holdings.text: Provisions of r.16(2) discriminate against imported hides/skins tanned outside State and contravene Art.304(a).
Impugned rule invalid; old rule does not revive.

precedents_cited.case_name: Atiabari Tea Co. Ltd. v. The State of Assam and Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.301 guarantees freedom from direct/immediate restrictions on trade movement; taxes directly restricting fall under Part XIII.

precedents_cited.case_name: Automobile Transport Rajasthan Ltd. etc. v. The State of Rajasthan and Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Clarifies regulatory/compensatory measures not hit by Art.301; sales tax not such unless non-discriminatory.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ujjam Bai v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Does not bar petition where tax assessed under invalid rule, lacking jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for petition; freedom of trade; prohibition on discriminatory taxes on inter-state goods.

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Charging section; single point taxation for hides/skins; rule-making power.

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Sales Tax Turnover Assessment Rules, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Prescribes single point for tax on hides/skins; held discriminatory in sub-r.(2).

outcome.summary: The Court held r.16(2) of the Rules invalid as discriminatory under Art.304(a), striking down the assessment basis; old rule does not revive; preliminary objection to maintainability dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: Impugned rule provision struck down; petition allowed implicitly.

key_quotes.text: "Does the impugned restriction operate directly or immediately on trade or its movement?"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test from Atiabari for Art.301 applicability.

key_quotes.text: "The similarity contemplated by Art. 304(a) is in the nature of the quality and kind of the goods and not with respect to whether they were subject of a tax already or not."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Once the old rule has been substituted by the new rule, it ceases to exist and it does not automatically get revived when the new rule is held to be invalid."
key_quotes.speaker: court
